The Blue Key Society, an organization formed at the Hopkins last year for the purpose

club will each be given a specific
hour in the week when he will

From New York
The College Bowl program
which originates live from New
York each week pits two teams
of. four representatives against
one another in a general scholastic contest. The winner each
week receives $1,500 for the
school's scholarship fund, and
the loser receives $500.
The Hopkins team will face
one of four possible schools in
its initial appearance. These
schools are: Miami of Ohio, Colorado State, Sweet Briar, and
Hanover College,
G.E. Gifts
The four members of the Hopkins team will be presented with
gifts from G.E. privately. No
student may appear on the show
who has been paid for a television appearance previously.
Some of the subjects covered
by the questions asked on the
show include the following: ancient and modern European history; American history; American, English, and European literature;
philosophy, science,
mathematics, economics, current
affairs, classical and popular
music, art, mythology, and the
Bible.

Council Stands Firm
On HC Replacement
By KEN NOBEL
The officers of the Student
Council have requested again
this week that Jim Payne be
replaced as Honor Commission
representative to the Council.
This action was taken in spite
of an Honor Commission request
that Payne, in view of his excellent record as President of
that body, be given another
chance to redeem himself.
Faced with the adamant stand
of the Student Council, the
members of the Honor Commission have agreed to appoint a
new representative. Payne who
received a unanimous vote of
confidence, will, however, remain
as Commission President.
Executive Request
This week, at the request of
the Council's Executive Committee, Brian Henderson sat in

on the meeting as a non-voting
representative of the Honor
Commission. The final appointment, however, has not yet been
made.
In another vein, the Council
took action this week to solve the
troublesome question of a codified operating procedure for the
SAC. A set of by-laws governing the SAC have been drawn up
by the officers of the Council
and have been submitted to Al
Freeland, President of the SAC,
for consideration. Freeland will
then send the proposal to Dean
Morrill for final approval.
Election Procedures
While the proVisions of these
proposed by-laws are not yet
finalized, they are reported to
deal with the question of election procedures for the SAC
which has been a bone of contention all year.

ass Presents Prom Plans
"So far ticket sales have been
encouraging,"
quite
Richard
Bass, chairman of the University
Prom, announced today.
Bass went on to add that "This
year the University Prom is
operating on its biggest budget
yet and promises to be one of
the highlights of this season."
The Prom which features the
world renowned Count Basie
Orchestra will be held on March
11 at the 5th Regiment Armory.
Tickets are currently on sale at
Levering Hall during lunch and
dinner hours, the dormitory
cafeteria during the same hours,
the student shop, Hampton
House, the Hopkins Medical
school. and by mail.
Mail Orders
- Bass asked that all tickets pur-

chased by mail be sent to him
care of box 607, JHU, Baltimore
18, Maryland.
Graduate tickets are priced at
$4.00 and undergraduate tickets
are $2.00.
Reserved Tables
Bass also announced that table
reservations are now available
at the student shop. Reservations cost $2.50 apiece.
"Since tickets will not be sold
at the door, the dance committee
urges that the tickets be purchased as soon as possible."
Bass added that set-ups including ice, soda, potato chips
and pretzels will be provided at
the dance.
Larger Area
According to Bass, "This year,
even though more tables will be

set up than last year, more
dancing area will be provided
than in the past two years. The
committee has also arranged
with the armory to provide a
less slippery dance floor than
last year."
Bass concluded by stating
that: "This year's prom, with
Count Basie, is expected to draw
the largest crowd yet seen at a
University Prom. For the past
two years the number of nonundergraduates at the Prom has
been limited; I'd like to personally urge all graduate students,
University personnel, nurses and
medical students to attend, since
the dance is not intended for
undergraduates only."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 3, 1961

NEWS-LETTER

Construction Boom Grips Tau Beta Pi Lists Conrad Defines Role
Hopkins Medical School Eligible Students— Of Dorm Counselors

Construction activity in all its
many stages is becoming a commonplace sight at the Johns
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
The demolition of old landmarks, the planning and erection of new buildings and the
renovation of existing useful
structures are slowly but surely
creating a new environment for
the hospital, the School of Medicine and the School of Hygiene
and Public Health.
On the hospital lot have appeared the first visible signs of
the major project that will be
the focal point of Hospital construction activity for the next
two years—the building of a
Children's Medical and Surgical
Center. Demolition work has begun on the Thayer building located on the site selected for the
Children's Center, and temperory corridors and tunnels are
being built to help move traffic
during that period of construction when the northwest portion
of the main corridor and tunnel
are being rebuilt.
The Garrett Room, which has
provided lounge facilities fOr female physicians on the hospital
staff, also will have to be demolished. The facilities are being

rebuilt some 50 feet farther
south of the present location, off
the main corridor behind the
Administration Building.

To replace the 44 semi-private
patient beds lost by the demolition of the Thayer Building, two
new floors have been built and
opened atop the Halsted and
Osier Buildings. Known as the
Finney and Thayer floors, they
will contain accommodations for
66 semi-private patients.
A new radiotherapy unit has
been opened in the Halsted basement. In addition to patient examining and servicing stations,
the new installation contains
five units for patient care and
research in deep X-ray therapy,
including a cobalt 60 unit rated
at 4,000 curies and a 2,000,000
electron volt generator.
The Wilmer outpatient department is being remodeled completely with the work scheduled
to be completed in March. Renovating work is beginning on
the fourth floor of the Carnegie
Dispensary where the department of otolaryngology will be
housed. This area was vacated
by the private patient clinic, now
located in sumptuous new guar(Continued on Page 6)

Alters Program

Tau Beta Pi, the National
Honorary Engineering Fraternity, has completed its list of
students who will be eligible for
membership in the society for
this semester.
Averages have been complied
by present members, and those
eligible are juniors in the top
eighth of their class and seniors
in the top fifth of their class.
Because of the importance of
the society, and what it stands
for, the program that will precede actual membership has been
adopted and planned so that
mature, serious objectives will
take precedent over actions
which do not reflect the true
character of the stature of the
society. In fact, according to
Bob Walinchus, who is in charge
of the 'pre-membership' program, "everything planned for
the students will have direct
benefit and purpose, and will
add to the position of the organization, not detract from it."
He gave assurance that no
longer would students be 'pledging' Tau Beta Pi, and there
would be no connotation of
pledging. It would be replaced
by a more beneficial program.

In response to questioning at
the Student Council meeting last
week, Keith Conrad defined the
steps which are being taken to
install seven new "counselors"
in the Dorms next year.
According to Conrad, the proposal is still in the planning
stage as far as the DSRC is concerned. A committee has been
appointed .to investigate the
matter, which was proposed by
the administration.
Not Proctors

As defined by Conrad, the
role of the new Dorm residents
will be to act as counselors and
advisors to the Dorm students.
He stated that they will not be
"proctors" in the accepted sense
of the word, but that their main
function will be an advisory one.
These men are envisioned as
slightly older, more experienced
persons who will be in a position to help the students with
their problems as an academic
advisor cannot.
The reason given for the raise
in the number of dorm counselors from three to seven is
that with more advisors there
is a greater likelihood that students of •different temperaments
will find someone of their own

Unfavorable Light

Conrad also deplored the fact
that Dick Barter is viewed in
such an unfavorable light by so
many residents of the Dormotories. Conrad stated that it is
unfortunate that Barter got off
to such a bad start, blaming the
News-Letter for much of the bad
feeling which has evolved around
him. Barter's sincere desire to
help the students was stressed
and Conrad felt that if more
people would go to him with
their troubles they would see
that he sincerely wants to help
them and is eminently qualified
to do so.

Brotherhood Week
The Brotherhood Week just past was without a
doubt the most interesting week of this school year. A
disarmament conference, Arnold Toynbee, Nina Simone,
Clarence Mitchell, and the various other events included
therein roused this campus from its semester-long lethargy
and gave undergraduates an indication of what they've
been missing.
The purpose of all these activities was to remind
Hopkins students of the need for brotherhood among men
during these troubled times. We hear about it all the
time, read about it. Seldom do we think about it, and
even less, practice it.
But college students like to consider themselves the
epitome of "thinking men." If this be so, then it should
be self-evident that they would constantly reappraise and
re-examine the value-systems by which they live.
Character growth is an essential of any sound education. Even Hopkins holds it as one of its aims (see catalog, p. 12). The truly educated man should be prepared
to contribute to society's moral as well as to its material
advancement. But if he thinks only of the differences
between himself and others, or sits back while others
derogate a man for his color or his religion he is offering
evidence that his education hasn't even begun.
The News-Letter offers congratulations to all concerned for a magnificent Brotherhood Week. We hope that
their efforts have not been in vain.

College Bowl
The news that dear old Johnny Hop has been chosen
to match wits and brains against students from other
universities and colleges on the TV show—General Electric's College Bowl—is most welcome, though not so
reassuring.
There's no doubt at all that we have many qualified
students who could easily walk away with the honors, and
to those who are chosen we certainly add our congratulations.
What bothers us is how come we weren't chosen a
long time ago?

and
equally long

ignored as far as any action is

courses in foreign and ancient

"I'VE GOT NEWS FOR YOU"
I know all of you have important things to do in the morning—
like getting down to breakfast before your roommate eats all
the marmalade—so you really cannot be blamed for not keeping
UP with all the news in the morning papers. In today's column,
therefore, I have prepared a run-up of news highlights from
campuses the country over.
SOUTHERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
Dr. Willard Hale Sigafoos, head of the department of anthropology at Southern Reserve University, and internationally
known as an authority on primitive peoples, returned yesterday
from a four-year scientific expedition to the headwaters of the
Amazon River. Among the many interesting mementos of his
journey is his own head, shrunk to the size of a kumquat. He
refused to reveal how his head shrinking was accomplished.
"That's for me to know and you to find out," he said with a
tiny, but saucy grin.
NORTHERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
Dr. Mandrill 'Gibbon, head of the department of zoology at
Northern Reserve University, and known to young and old for
his work on primates, announced yesterday that he had received a grant of $80,000,000 for a twelve-year study to determine precisely how much fun there is in a barrel of monkeys.
Whatever the results of Dr. Gibbon's researches, this much
is already known: What's more fun than a barrel of monkeys is

EASTERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
The annual meeting of the American Philological Institute,
held last week at Eastern Reserve University, was enlivened
by the reading of two divergent monographs concerning the
origins of early Gothic "runes," as letters of primitive alphabets
are called.
Dr. Tristram Lathrop Spleen, famed far and wide as the discoverer of the High German Consonant Shift, read a paper in
Which he traced the origins of the Old Wendish rune "pt"
(Pronounced "krahtz") to the middle Lettic rune "gr" (proBounced "albert"). On the other hand, Dr. Richard Cummerbund Twonkey, who, as the whole world knows, translated
"The Pajama Game" into Middle High Bactrian, contended
in his paper that the Old Wendish rune "pt" derives from the
Low Erse rune "mf" (pronounced "gr").
Well, sir the discussion grew so heated that Dr. Twonkey
finally asked Dr. Spleen if he would like to step into the gymnasium and put on the gloves. Dr. Spleen accepted the challenge promptly, but the contest was never held because there
Were no gloves in the gymnasium that would fit Dr. Twonkey.
(The reader is doubtless finding this hard to believe as
Eastern Reserve University is celebrated the length and breadth
of the land for the size of its glove collection. However, the
reader is asked to remember that Dr. Twonkey has extraordinarily small hands and arms. In fact, he spent the last
War working in a small-arms plant, where lie received two
Navy "E" Awards and was widely hailed as a "manly little

By JOEL GORDON
At Hopkins there is only one reason for a ball player
to come out for a sport: a genuine love of the game. There
are no scholarships, but even more hard to swallow is that
there is no student support.
This might well be a reason why the hoop squad
posted such a poor record this year. It can't be blamed on
the players because these same hoopsters as Freshmen in
the previous years lost a total of 4 games in 25 against
the same competition.
The real difference is that the hoopsters lacked the
desire to win because it made very little difference to
anyone if they did. As the scores became worse and worse
the team soon lost all interest in ,the garrie itself. If the
team deserves any slaps on the back it is for having the
guts to stick with what they soon considered a bad mistake,
especially when the time they spent with it hurt their
scholastic standings. It can be predicted with almost
startling accuracy that all but two will not be back for
more next year. But that's sports at Hopkins.

rirosh Close Season
VARSITY
In the final dual meet before
the MA championships this Saturday, the Varsity beat Haverlord 19-8. The Sabre and epee
teams led with smashing 9-0
and 8-1 victories.
In Sabre, Appel, Karol, Smith
and Koehler were undefeated, in
epee the laurels went to McNamara, Twyman and Venza,
while Ahern won 2 and dropped 1 by a very close 5-4 margin. Vaughan was blanked in
foil, but Loebner and Bockman
each took 1 out of 3.
Looking to the M-A's this Saturday, Coach Oles plans to send
Dick Bockman and Paul Smith
in foil, Lee Appel and Paul Karol
in sabre, and Tom Ahern and
either Lon Venza or Tom McNamara in epee. Tom Ahern,
Appel and Karol plan to repeat
their capture of the Sabre team
trophy, while Appel himself is
looking to repeat as M.A. sabre
king.
As a final tuneup, the epee
team traveled to Washington
Tuesday night to fence the U.S.
Modern Pentatholon epee team.
The whole Hopkins team took
on the Martin fencing club on
Wednesday.
Coach Oles thinks that his
boys will be well-primed for the
big events, and has cautiously
hinted that "with a little luck
and heads-up ball, we may win
it."

—FRESHMEN
Traveling to Valley Forge last
Wednesday, the freshmen fencers ended their season with
an 11-16 loss. Although both the
sabre and epee teams won by
6-3 and 5-4 scores, respectively,
the foil team was shut out 9-0.
Double bout winners included
Sherm Teichman and Dick
Satava in sabre, and Fred Eustis
in epee. Single bout winners were
Don Davison and Bob Carroll in
sabre, and Dan Searing, Ted
Parlette and Dick Harrison in
epee.
. Looking back over the freshman season, Coach Dick Oles
made these remarks:
"The sabre team of Carroll,
Satava, Davidson and Teichman
is the strongest we've had in
years. It beat all opponenets including the highly rated Navy
Plebes, and promises to become
varsity
powerful
really
a
nucleus.
"Fencing at the freshman
level is rough, since all our opponents are military or prep
schools who have been fencing
2 years longer that we have.
That a Hopkins freshman team
can come close to ( or beat) these
schools is an indication of the
good potential of Hopkins fencing.
"Outstanding fencers on the
yearling squad include Teichman, Satava, Carroll and Davidson in sabre, and Eustis in Epee."

Dorm Advisors
To the Editors:
I have refrained this year from
the popular fad of criticizing
campus organizations because I
think that a great deal of the
Solution lies in student attitudes
and desire for effective student
government. However, I feel that
I must make a few remarks
about the present situation in
the D.S.R.C. It seems that
elected bodies must constantly
be reminded that they were
elected and are in theory at least
subject to the will of the electorate.
In the present discussion of
the D.S.R.C. the feasibility of
having more dorm advisors has
been referred to committee, Notice that the matter was not
tabled for a few weeks in order
to ascertain student opinion, it
was sent to a committee for discussion. This addition of advisors, a rather poorly disguised
maneuver by the Administration,

I believe in the Gentleman's
Code and the Hopkins traditions
that we are all considered mature enough to go to classes
and attend to our daily affairs
without the need of Big Brothers. To me, the most lamentable
aspect of this situation is that
the Administration is getting exactly what it wants from the
D.S.R.C.—student endorsement
of a curtailment of student freedom. I therefore suggest that
since the D.S.R.C. seems to have
no intention of submitting this
proposal to the dorms in a plebiscite, and I feel it is important
enough for such action, that the
dorm students should avail
themselves of every opportunity
of protest by attending the
D.S.R.C. meetings and writing
the News-Letter Fraternity men

Council Stands Firm
On HC Replacement
By KEN NOBEL
The officers of the Student
Council have requested again
this week that Jim Payne be
replaced as Honor Commission
representative to the Council.
This action was taken in spite
of an Honor Commission request
that Payne, in view of his excellent record as President of
that body, be given another
chance to redeem himself.
Faced with the adamant stand
of the Student Council, the
members of the Honor Commission have agreed to appoint a
new representative. Payne who
received a unanimous vote of
confidence, will, however, remain
as Commission President.
Executive Request
This week, at the request of
the Council's Executive Committee, Brian Henderson sat in

on the meeting as a non-voting
representative of the Honor
Commission. The final appointment, however, has not yet been
made.
In another vein, the Council
took action this week to solve the
troublesome question of a codified operating procedure for the
SAC. A set of by-laws governing the SAC have been drawn up
by the officers of the Council
and have been submitted to Al
Freeland, President of the SAC,
for consideration. Freeland will
then send the proposal to Dean
Morrill for final approval.
Election Procedures
While the proVisions of these
proposed by-laws are not yet
finalized, they are reported to
deal with the question of election procedures for the SAC
which has been a bone of contention all year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 3, 1961

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE TWO

Construction Boom Grips Tau Beta Pi Lists Conrad Defines Role
Hopkins Medical School Eligible Students— Of Dorm Counselors

Construction activity in all its
many stages is becoming a commonplace sight at the Johns
Hopkins Medical Institutions.
The demolition of old landmarks, the planning and erection of new buildings and the
renovation of existing useful
structures are slowly but surely
creating a new environment for
the hospital, the School of Medicine and the School of Hygiene
and Public Health.
On the hospital lot have appeared the first visible signs of
the major project that will be
the focal point of Hospital construction activity for the next
two years—the building of a
Children's Medical and Surgical
Center. Demolition work has begun on the Thayer building located on the site selected for the
Children's Center, and temperory corridors and tunnels are
being built to help move traffic
during that period of construction when the northwest portion
of the main corridor and tunnel
are being rebuilt.
The Garrett Room, which has
provided lounge facilities fOr female physicians on the hospital
staff, also will have to be demolished. The facilities are being

rebuilt some 50 feet farther
south of the present location, off
the main corridor behind the
Administration Building.

To replace the 44 semi-private
patient beds lost by the demolition of the Thayer Building, two
new floors have been built and
opened atop the Halsted and
Osier Buildings. Known as the
Finney and Thayer floors, they
will contain accommodations for
66 semi-private patients.
A new radiotherapy unit has
been opened in the Halsted basement. In addition to patient examining and servicing stations,
the new installation contains
five units for patient care and
research in deep X-ray therapy,
including a cobalt 60 unit rated
at 4,000 curies and a 2,000,000
electron volt generator.
The Wilmer outpatient department is being remodeled completely with the work scheduled
to be completed in March. Renovating work is beginning on
the fourth floor of the Carnegie
Dispensary where the department of otolaryngology will be
housed. This area was vacated
by the private patient clinic, now
located in sumptuous new guar(Continued on Page 6)

Alters Program

Tau Beta Pi, the National
Honorary Engineering Fraternity, has completed its list of
students who will be eligible for
membership in the society for
this semester.
Averages have been complied
by present members, and those
eligible are juniors in the top
eighth of their class and seniors
in the top fifth of their class.

benefit and purpose, and will

longer would students be 'pledging' Tau Beta Pi, and there
would be no connotation of

by a more beneficial program.

slightly older, more experienced
persons who will be in a position to help the students with
their problems as an academic
advisor cannot.

in the number of dorm counselors from three to seven is
that with more advisors there
is a greater likelihood that students of •different temperaments

Brotherhood Week
The Brotherhood Week just past was without a
doubt the most interesting week of this school year. A
disarmament conference, Arnold Toynbee, Nina Simone,
Clarence Mitchell, and the various other events included
therein roused this campus from its semester-long lethargy
and gave undergraduates an indication of what they've
been missing.
The purpose of all these activities was to remind
Hopkins students of the need for brotherhood among men
during these troubled times. We hear about it all the
time, read about it. Seldom do we think about it, and
even less, practice it.
But college students like to consider themselves the
epitome of "thinking men." If this be so, then it should
be self-evident that they would constantly reappraise and
re-examine the value-systems by which they live.
Character growth is an essential of any sound education. Even Hopkins holds it as one of its aims (see catalog, p. 12). The truly educated man should be prepared
to contribute to society's moral as well as to its material
advancement. But if he thinks only of the differences
between himself and others, or sits back while others
derogate a man for his color or his religion he is offering
evidence that his education hasn't even begun.
The News-Letter offers congratulations to all concerned for a magnificent Brotherhood Week. We hope that
their efforts have not been in vain.

College Bowl
The news that dear old Johnny Hop has been chosen
to match wits and brains against students from other
universities and colleges on the TV show—General Electric's College Bowl—is most welcome, though not so
reassuring.
There's no doubt at all that we have many qualified
students who could easily walk away with the honors, and
to those who are chosen we certainly add our congratulations.
What bothers us is how come we weren't chosen a
long time ago?

"I'VE GOT NEWS FOR YOU"
I know all of you have important things to do in the morning—
like getting down to breakfast before your roommate eats all
the marmalade—so you really cannot be blamed for not keeping
UP with all the news in the morning papers. In today's column,
therefore, I have prepared a run-up of news highlights from
campuses the country over.
SOUTHERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
Dr. Willard Hale Sigafoos, head of the department of anthropology at Southern Reserve University, and internationally
known as an authority on primitive peoples, returned yesterday
from a four-year scientific expedition to the headwaters of the
Amazon River. Among the many interesting mementos of his
journey is his own head, shrunk to the size of a kumquat. He
refused to reveal how his head shrinking was accomplished.
"That's for me to know and you to find out," he said with a
tiny, but saucy grin.
NORTHERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
Dr. Mandrill 'Gibbon, head of the department of zoology at
Northern Reserve University, and known to young and old for
his work on primates, announced yesterday that he had received a grant of $80,000,000 for a twelve-year study to determine precisely how much fun there is in a barrel of monkeys.
Whatever the results of Dr. Gibbon's researches, this much
is already known: What's more fun than a barrel of monkeys is

EASTERN RESERVE UNIVERSITY
The annual meeting of the American Philological Institute,
held last week at Eastern Reserve University, was enlivened
by the reading of two divergent monographs concerning the
origins of early Gothic "runes," as letters of primitive alphabets
are called.
Dr. Tristram Lathrop Spleen, famed far and wide as the discoverer of the High German Consonant Shift, read a paper in
Which he traced the origins of the Old Wendish rune "pt"
(Pronounced "krahtz") to the middle Lettic rune "gr" (proBounced "albert"). On the other hand, Dr. Richard Cummerbund Twonkey, who, as the whole world knows, translated
"The Pajama Game" into Middle High Bactrian, contended
in his paper that the Old Wendish rune "pt" derives from the
Low Erse rune "mf" (pronounced "gr").
Well, sir the discussion grew so heated that Dr. Twonkey
finally asked Dr. Spleen if he would like to step into the gymnasium and put on the gloves. Dr. Spleen accepted the challenge promptly, but the contest was never held because there
Were no gloves in the gymnasium that would fit Dr. Twonkey.
(The reader is doubtless finding this hard to believe as
Eastern Reserve University is celebrated the length and breadth
of the land for the size of its glove collection. However, the
reader is asked to remember that Dr. Twonkey has extraordinarily small hands and arms. In fact, he spent the last
War working in a small-arms plant, where lie received two
Navy "E" Awards and was widely hailed as a "manly little

Statistics, however, do not tell
half the story for the season. Ratner, despite figures which were
not eye popping, did much to
spark the team and had many
rebounds and shots.
clutch
Homer Schwartz and Phil Berger, the front court men, whose
positions are not the best for
making points or snaring rebounds, led the team on the floor,
and set up many of the shots
which were used to figure the
statistical total. Because of the
exceptional team quality of the
players, it is difficult to say that
they were the spirit which
sparked the team, but they were
always there, playing steady
ball, and coming up with fine
plays at critical moments.
Not to be overlooked, of course,
is the 'fine job that the frosh
reserve corps, led by White, John
Heller, and Pete Thompson, did
when called upon. These three
were frequently sent in to relieve
one of the starters, and always
came through with an excellent
performance. The fine work of
the trio was accentuated in the
Dickinson game, where the work
they had done all season suddenly became obvious, and they
played no small role in the
team's final victory.
The cohesiveness of the team,
both on and off the field, was
due in no small measure to the
fine coaching and leadership of
the frosh mentor, Robert H.
Scott. By hard work, perserverence, and an unfaltering confidence in the team, the coach
welded a team which began the
season with two straight losses
into a cohesive, powerful, and
winning unit.

By HERB DORSEY
A three way contest for top
honors looms this weekend in the
Mason-Dixon Wrestling Tournament at Homewood. Hopkins
Mickey
Cochrane's
coach
charges:fresh from a 36 to 3
clobbering of Catholic University, are rated as co-favorites
with Baltimore University and
American University.
Coach Cochrane feels that the
previous weeks' matches against
tough Middle Atlantic competition were very helpful in .preparing the grapplers for their
return to the relatively weaker
Mason-Dixon Conference.
The Blue Jays will field a
powerful squad which has plenty
of overall strength and quite a
few shots at "top ,money", in the
classes. Both Baltimore U. and
American U. have rounded out
somewhat shallow rosters with
recent February graduates of
high,schools; B.U. in particular
adding last year's Maryland
Scholastic Association 123 pound
champion.
Some lucky breaks on the
drawing for byes and good seedings for the leading grapplers
will help the Hopkins cause immeasurably. With every team
entering at least one strong
wrestler, there should be a lot
of upsets.
Don Haynie will be going for
Hopkins at 123 lb. and should
encounter most of his difficulty
with the Bee grappler and Towson's Lee Orlando. Ron Davis
will follow Haynie at the 130
pound spot.
Steve Jaffee will return to the
mat wars after almost a month's
layoff because of an injury. Jaffee could conceivably get the
number one seed if his absence
does not weigh too heavily.
Tom Winslow steps into a
rough 147 lb. class while Dale
Gobel will be grappling at 157
lb. for the first year. Steadily
improving Roger Morrison will

grapple at 167 lb. Against Catholic U. Morrison displayed tremendous courage in coming back
from a 2-0 deficit with 30 seconds to go to pin his opponent.
Buff Ward will be the Jay's
177 pound representative and
Dave Rowe will go at 191. Rowe

is also fighting inactivity since
Middle
Atlantic
Conference
matches do not have a 191 pound
class.
Heavyweight Jim Kelly is easily the best bet for unlimited class
honors. Kelly holds a fantastic

By JOEL GORDON
At Hopkins there is only one reason for a ball player
to come out for a sport: a genuine love of the game. There
are no scholarships, but even more hard to swallow is that
there is no student support.
This might well be a reason why the hoop squad
posted such a poor record this year. It can't be blamed on
the players because these same hoopsters as Freshmen in
the previous years lost a total of 4 games in 25 against
the same competition.
The real difference is that the hoopsters lacked the
desire to win because it made very little difference to
anyone if they did. As the scores became worse and worse
the team soon lost all interest in ,the garrie itself. If the
team deserves any slaps on the back it is for having the
guts to stick with what they soon considered a bad mistake,
especially when the time they spent with it hurt their
scholastic standings. It can be predicted with almost
startling accuracy that all but two will not be back for
more next year. But that's sports at Hopkins.

Fencers Seek Title;
rirosh Close Season
VARSITY
In the final dual meet before
the MA championships this Saturday, the Varsity beat Haverlord 19-8. The Sabre and epee
teams led with smashing 9-0
and 8-1 victories.
In Sabre, Appel, Karol, Smith
and Koehler were undefeated, in
epee the laurels went to McNamara, Twyman and Venza,
while Ahern won 2 and dropped 1 by a very close 5-4 margin. Vaughan was blanked in
foil, but Loebner and Bockman
each took 1 out of 3.
Looking to the M-A's this Saturday, Coach Oles plans to send
Dick Bockman and Paul Smith
in foil, Lee Appel and Paul Karol
in sabre, and Tom Ahern and
either Lon Venza or Tom McNamara in epee. Tom Ahern,
Appel and Karol plan to repeat
their capture of the Sabre team
trophy, while Appel himself is
looking to repeat as M.A. sabre
king.
As a final tuneup, the epee
team traveled to Washington
Tuesday night to fence the U.S.
Modern Pentatholon epee team.
The whole Hopkins team took
on the Martin fencing club on
Wednesday.
Coach Oles thinks that his
boys will be well-primed for the
big events, and has cautiously
hinted that "with a little luck
and heads-up ball, we may win
it."

—FRESHMEN
Traveling to Valley Forge last
Wednesday, the freshmen fencers ended their season with
an 11-16 loss. Although both the
sabre and epee teams won by
6-3 and 5-4 scores, respectively,
the foil team was shut out 9-0.
Double bout winners included
Sherm Teichman and Dick
Satava in sabre, and Fred Eustis
in epee. Single bout winners were
Don Davison and Bob Carroll in
sabre, and Dan Searing, Ted
Parlette and Dick Harrison in
epee.
. Looking back over the freshman season, Coach Dick Oles
made these remarks:
"The sabre team of Carroll,
Satava, Davidson and Teichman
is the strongest we've had in
years. It beat all opponenets including the highly rated Navy
Plebes, and promises to become
varsity
powerful
really
a
nucleus.
"Fencing at the freshman
level is rough, since all our opponents are military or prep
schools who have been fencing
2 years longer that we have.
That a Hopkins freshman team
can come close to ( or beat) these
schools is an indication of the
good potential of Hopkins fencing.
"Outstanding fencers on the
yearling squad include Teichman, Satava, Carroll and Davidson in sabre, and Eustis in Epee."

To the Editors:
I have refrained this year from
the popular fad of criticizing
campus organizations because I
think that a great deal of the
Solution lies in student attitudes
and desire for effective student
government. However, I feel that
I must make a few remarks
about the present situation in
the D.S.R.C. It seems that
elected bodies must constantly
be reminded that they were
elected and are in theory at least
subject to the will of the electorate.
In the present discussion of
the D.S.R.C. the feasibility of
having more dorm advisors has
been referred to committee, Notice that the matter was not
tabled for a few weeks in order

was sent to a committee for discussion. This addition of advisors, a rather poorly disguised
maneuver by the Administration,

I believe in the Gentleman's
Code and the Hopkins traditions

since the D.S.R.C. seems to have
no intention of submitting this
proposal to the dorms in a plebiscite, and I feel it is important
enough for such action, that the
dorm students should avail
themselves of every opportunity

ART EXHIBIT—
From March 1 to the beginning of Spring vacation, the
Hopkins YMCA is sponsoring
an art exhibit in the Sherwood Rooms. The exhibit
consists of 26 paintings by 26
artists from the Baltimore
and Maryland area, who have
united in organization known
as the Maryland Artists'
Equity. The Sherwood Room is
open to the public from 9 to
on weekdays and at other
times by special arrangement.
